markdownRemark.html:
Starting from this post, we are going to apply the techniques we learned in QM to solve some real-world problems. In this post, we are going to describe the hydrogen atom with Quantum Mechanics!

  • QM in 3-D
  • Hamiltonian for Two Particles in Center of Mass Frame
  • Separation of Variables
  • Solving the Angular Equation
  • Solving the Radial Equation
  • References

QM in 3-D

We’ve been doing QM in 1-D for a long time now and that assumption has almost become explicit. However, the hydrogen atom is a three dimensional structure that obviously requires more sophisticated treatment. It necessitates an understanding of QM in 3-D. After that, we will write out the Hamiltonian for a hydrogen atom and solve the Schrodinger equation in 3-D. This will give us the energy eigenfunctions, which describe the shape of the electron orbitals we know well from chemistry.

Thankfully, adding two additional dimensions is not a hard adjustment to make. We just need to make sure that every 1-D quantity/expression/operation finds its 3-D correspondence. Here is a table that summarizes all the essential changes.

Hamiltonian for Two Particles in Center of Mass Frame

Now we try to write out the Hamiltonian of the hydrogen atom. The main components of a hydrogen atom are a proton and an electron. When analyzing two particle systems like this, it is convenient to transform to the center of mass frame and express things there.

Consider the most general case where we have particles 1 and 2. We have:

RCM=m1r1+m2r2m1+m2\pmb{R_{CM}} = \frac {m_1\pmb{r_1} + m_2\pmb{r_2}}{m_1+m_2}RCM​RCM​=m1​+m2​m1​r1​r1​+m2​r2​r2​​ vCM=m1r1˙+m2r2˙m1+m2\pmb{v_{CM}} = \frac {m_1\dot {\pmb{r_1}} + m_2 \dot {\pmb{r_2}}}{m_1+m_2}vCM​vCM​=m1​+m2​m1​r1​r1​˙​+m2​r2​r2​˙​​

In the “normal” frame (lab frame), we can easily write out the Hamiltonian of the two particle system as:

H^=p1^22m1+p2^22m2+V(r1^−r2^)\hat H = \frac {\hat {\pmb{p_1}}^2 } {2m_1} + \frac {\hat {\pmb{p_2}}^2 } {2m_2} + V(\hat {\pmb{r_1}} - \hat {\pmb{r_2}})H^=2m1​p1​p1​^​2​+2m2​p2​p2​^​2​+V(r1​r1​^​−r2​r2​^​)

Where we have expressed the kinetic energy simply as the sum of the kinetic energy of the two particles. In the center of mass frame, we seek a similar approach. The only difference is that we think of kinetic energy as coming from two components: the kinetic energy of the motion of the center of mass and the kinetic energy of relative motion. The kinetic energy from the motion of the center of mass is easily expressed as:

P22M\frac { {\pmb{P}}^2 }{2M}2MPP2​

where:

P^=p1^+p2^\hat {\pmb P} = \hat {\pmb{p_1}} + \hat {\pmb{p_2}}PP^=p1​p1​^​+p2​p2​^​ M=m1+m2M = m_1 + m_2M=m1​+m2​

The kinetic energy from relative motion is a bit tricky. We start from consider the momentum of particle 1 in the center of mass frame:

prel=(p1)CM=m1(v1−vCM)=m1m2v1−m2v2m1+m2=m1m2m1+m2(v1−v2)\begin{aligned} \pmb{p_{rel}} &= (\pmb{p_1})_{CM} \\ &= m_1 (\pmb{v_1}-\pmb{v_{CM}}) \\ &= m_1\frac{m_2\pmb{v_1}-m_2\pmb{v_2}}{m_1+m_2} \\ &= \frac {m_1m_2}{m_1 +m_2} (\pmb{v_1}-\pmb{v_2}) \end{aligned}prel​prel​​=(p1​p1​)CM​=m1​(v1​v1​−vCM​vCM​)=m1​m1​+m2​m2​v1​v1​−m2​v2​v2​​=m1​+m2​m1​m2​​(v1​v1​−v2​v2​)​

Comparing the final form of this expression with p=mv\pmb p = m\pmb vpp=mvv, we can define a new mass called the reduced mass:

μ=m1m2m1+m2\mu = \frac{m_1m_2}{m_1+m_2}μ=m1​+m2​m1​m2​​

and call:

v=v1−v2\pmb v= \pmb{v_1}-\pmb{v_2}vv=v1​v1​−v2​v2​ r=r1−r2\pmb r= \pmb{r_1}-\pmb{r_2}rr=r1​r1​−r2​r2​

Relative velocity and relative position.

Thus, we can write the Hamiltonian in a new way:

H^=P^22M+prel^22μ+V(r^)\hat H = \frac {\hat {\pmb P}^2 } {2M} + \frac {\hat {\pmb{p_{rel}}}^2 } {2\mu} + V(\hat {\pmb r})H^=2MPP^2​+2μprel​prel​^​2​+V(rr^)

Essentially, we have converted the momentum variables from (p1,p2)(\pmb{p_1}, \pmb{p_2})(p1​p1​,p2​p2​) to (prel,P)(\pmb{p_{rel}}, \pmb P)(prel​prel​,PP) and correspondingly converted the position variables from (r1,r2)(\pmb{r_1}, \pmb{r_2})(r1​r1​,r2​r2​) to (r,RCM)(\pmb r, \pmb{R_{CM}})(rr,RCM​RCM​).

To check that this transformation is valid even with all the operator symbols, we just need to check the commutator relationships between the various position and momentum variables/operators. I won’t go through that derivation here since it’s simple but tedious.

We can do a couple more simplifications to out center of mass frame Hamiltonian. Assuming we are in the center of mass frame, the first term describing the kinetic energy of the center of mass goes to 0. Furthermore, with the Coulomb potential present in hydrogen atoms, the potential energy term is only dependent on the separation of the two particles (such potentials are called central potentials). With these information in mind, we can write our Hamiltonian as:

H^=p^22μ+V(r)=−ℏ22μ∇2+V(r)\hat H = \frac{\hat {\pmb p}^2}{2\mu} + V(r) = - \frac{\hbar^2}{2\mu} \nabla ^2 + V(r)H^=2μpp^​2​+V(r)=−2μℏ2​∇2+V(r)

Separation of Variables

We now want to solve the Schrodinger equation:

(−ℏ22μ∇2+V(r))ψ(r)=Eψ(r)(- \frac{\hbar^2}{2\mu} \nabla ^2 + V(r)) \psi_{(\pmb r)} = E \psi_{(\pmb r)}(−2μℏ2​∇2+V(r))ψ(rr)​=Eψ(rr)​

The first step in solving the Schrodinger equation is to expand out the del operator in the Hamiltonian. We know that the hydrogen atom is a spherically symmetric structure, so it is best to expand out del in spherical coordinates:

∇2=1r2∂∂r(r2∂∂r)+1r2sin⁡θ∂∂θ(sin⁡θ∂∂θ)+1r2sin⁡2θ∂2∂ϕ2\nabla^2 = \frac{1}{r^2} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}(r^2\frac{\partial}{\partial r}) + \frac{1}{r^2\sin\theta}\frac{\partial}{\partial \theta} (\sin\theta \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta})+\frac{1}{r^2\sin^2\theta}\frac{\partial^2}{\partial \phi^2}∇2=r21​∂r∂​(r2∂r∂​)+r2sinθ1​∂θ∂​(sinθ∂θ∂​)+r2sin2θ1​∂ϕ2∂2​

Substitute del into the Schrodinger equation, we will get a single equation of three unknowns (r,θ,ϕr, \theta, \phir,θ,ϕ). A common approach to clean up this mess is to use a technique called separation of variables. The purpose of this technique is to manipulate the equation algebraically such that each term in the equation is only a function of one variable. Then, we can gather terms that dependent on the same variable on either sides of the equation. To have the two sides that depend on different variables equal to each other, the only way is to set both sides equal to a constant. This gives us to much simpler differential equations to solve. Let’s try to apply this technique to practice and see what happens.

First, we separate the wave function into a radial part and an angular part. Let:

ψ(r,θ,ϕ)=R(r)Y(θ,ϕ)\psi_{(r, \theta, \phi)} = R_{(r)} Y_{(\theta, \phi)}ψ(r,θ,ϕ)​=R(r)​Y(θ,ϕ)​

Substitute this form into the Schrodinger equation, we get:

−ℏ22μ[Yr2∂∂r(r2∂R∂r)+Rr2sin⁡θ∂∂θ(sin⁡θ∂Y∂θ)+Rr2sin⁡2θ∂2Y∂ϕ2]+V(r)RY=ERY- \frac{\hbar^2}{2\mu} [ \frac{Y}{r^2} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}(r^2\frac{\partial R}{\partial r})+\frac{R}{r^2\sin\theta}\frac{\partial}{\partial \theta} (\sin\theta \frac{\partial Y}{\partial \theta}) + \frac{R}{r^2\sin^2\theta}\frac{\partial^2 Y}{\partial \phi^2}] +V_{(r)}RY = ERY−2μℏ2​[r2Y​∂r∂​(r2∂r∂R​)+r2sinθR​∂θ∂​(sinθ∂θ∂Y​)+r2sin2θR​∂ϕ2∂2Y​]+V(r)​RY=ERY

Now we need to take out the Y’s in the r dependent terms and take out the R’s in the angle dependent terms. To do so, we multiply everything by −2μr2ℏ2-\frac {2\mu r^2}{\hbar^2}−ℏ22μr2​, divide by RY (which is just the wave function ψ\psiψ itself), and gather like terms. We get:

1Rddr(r2dRdr)−2μr2ℏ2[V(r)−E]=−1Y[1sin⁡θ∂∂θ(sin⁡θ∂Y∂θ)+1sin⁡2θ∂2Y∂ϕ2]\frac{1}{R} \frac{d}{dr}(r^2\frac{dR}{dr}) - \frac {2\mu r^2}{\hbar^2} [V_{(r)} - E] = -\frac{1}{Y} [\frac{1}{\sin\theta}\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta}(\sin\theta\frac{\partial Y}{\partial \theta})+\frac{1}{\sin^2\theta}\frac{\partial^2 Y}{\partial\phi^2}]R1​drd​(r2drdR​)−ℏ22μr2​[V(r)​−E]=−Y1​[sinθ1​∂θ∂​(sinθ∂θ∂Y​)+sin2θ1​∂ϕ2∂2Y​]

Now we see that the LHS is only dependent on r, and the RHS is only dependent on the angles. This means the only these two sides are equal to each other is that they are both equal to a constant. We define that constant to be l(l+1)l(l+1)l(l+1) and separate our result into two equations:

1Rddr(r2dRdr)−2μr2ℏ2[V(r)−E]=l(l+1)\frac{1}{R} \frac{d}{dr}(r^2\frac{dR}{dr}) - \frac {2\mu r^2}{\hbar^2} [V_{(r)} - E] = l(l+1)R1​drd​(r2drdR​)−ℏ22μr2​[V(r)​−E]=l(l+1) 1Y[1sin⁡θ∂∂θ(sin⁡θ∂Y∂θ)+1sin⁡2θ∂2Y∂ϕ2]=−l(l+1)\frac{1}{Y} [\frac{1}{\sin\theta}\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta}(\sin\theta\frac{\partial Y}{\partial \theta})+\frac{1}{\sin^2\theta}\frac{\partial^2 Y}{\partial\phi^2}] = -l(l+1)Y1​[sinθ1​∂θ∂​(sinθ∂θ∂Y​)+sin2θ1​∂ϕ2∂2Y​]=−l(l+1)

The first equation is known as the Radial Equation, and the second equation is known as the Angular Equation. We proceed to solve these two equations one at a time.

Solving the Angular Equation

We focus on the Angular Equation first. Note that this differential equation is still challenging to solve because there are two variables in it. Now you should know what to do. Use separation of variables once more!

Let:

Y=Θ(θ)Φ(ϕ)Y=\Theta_{(\theta)}\Phi_{(\phi)}Y=Θ(θ)​Φ(ϕ)​

Substitute in, divide by ΘΦ\Theta\PhiΘΦ, and rearrange, we get:

1Θ[sin⁡θddθ(sin⁡θdΘdθ)]−l(l+1)sin⁡θ=−1Φd2Φdϕ2\frac{1}{\Theta} [\sin\theta \frac{d}{d\theta}(\sin\theta\frac{d\Theta}{d\theta})] -l(l+1)\sin\theta = -\frac{1}{\Phi}\frac{d^2\Phi}{d\phi^2}Θ1​[sinθdθd​(sinθdθdΘ​)]−l(l+1)sinθ=−Φ1​dϕ2d2Φ​

Again, both sides need to be equal to a constant. let that constant be m2m^2m2, and look at the ϕ\phiϕ dependent part. we have:

d2Φdϕ2=−m2Φ\frac{d^2\Phi}{d\phi^2} = -m^2 \Phidϕ2d2Φ​=−m2Φ

Now we finally have something that’s easy to solve. The solution to this differential equation is obviously:

Φ(ϕ)=eimϕ\Phi_{(\phi)} = e^{im\phi}Φ(ϕ)​=eimϕ

If you still remember how we defined the wave function, you will see that this is only one-third of the solution. We carry on with the θ\thetaθ dependent part:

1Θ[sin⁡θddθ(sin⁡θdΘdθ)]−l(l+1)sin⁡θ=m2\frac{1}{\Theta} [\sin\theta \frac{d}{d\theta}(\sin\theta\frac{d\Theta}{d\theta})] -l(l+1)\sin\theta = m^2Θ1​[sinθdθd​(sinθdθdΘ​)]−l(l+1)sinθ=m2

The solution to this differential equation is:

Θ(θ)=APlm(cos⁡θ)\Theta_{(\theta)} = A P^m_l (\cos \theta)Θ(θ)​=APlm​(cosθ)

Where AAA is the normalization factor and PlmP^m_lPlm​ is the Legendre function. The formulae for the Legendre functions and the Legendre polynomials can be found in Townsend’s textbook.

Note that l,ml, ml,m in this case serves as a numbering system for the wave functions. The Legendre function imposes that:

m=0,±1,±2,...m=0,\pm 1, \pm 2, ...m=0,±1,±2,... l=0,1,2,...l=0, 1, 2, ...l=0,1,2,... ∣m∣≤l|m| \le l∣m∣≤l

From the angular wavefunction, we often two quantum numbers: mmm the magnetic quantum number as it is related to the magnetic properties of the hydrogen atom, lll the azimuthal quantum number because it is obtained from the azimuthal equation.

Now we can put the two parts together and obtain the complete solution to the angular part of the Schrodinger equation. Wave functions in 3-D need to be normalized in the angular and the radial part separately, so we already have enough information to compute the normalization factor for the angular wave function. After much algebra, we can obtain the result, which we call spherical harmonics (YlmY_{lm}Ylm​):

Ylm(θ,ϕ)=(−1)m(2l+1)(l−∣m∣)!4π(l+∣m∣)!eimϕPlm(cos⁡θ)Y_{lm (\theta , \phi)} = (-1)^m \sqrt{\frac{(2l+1)(l-|m|)!}{4\pi (l+|m|)!}} e^{im\phi} P^m_l (\cos \theta)Ylm(θ,ϕ)​=(−1)m4π(l+∣m∣)!(2l+1)(l−∣m∣)!​​eimϕPlm​(cosθ)

The relationship between lll and mmm should let you recall post 2 where we discussed angular momentum. Indeed, l(l+1)l(l+1)l(l+1) is also the eigenvalue of the total orbital momentum operator L^2\hat{L}^2L^2 (remember that we mysteriously set the constant to be l(l+1)l(l+1)l(l+1) in the derivation), and mmm is the eigenvalue of orbital momentum operator Lz^\hat{L_z}Lz​^​.

You can check the above claims by applying the operators to the spherical harmonics in the position space. In the position space,

Lz^=ℏi∂∂ϕ    L^=r^×p^=r×ℏi∇\hat{L_z} = \frac{\hbar}{i}\frac{\partial}{\partial \phi} \; \; \hat{L} = \hat{\pmb{r}} \times \hat{\pmb{p}} = \pmb{r} \times \frac{\hbar}{i} \nablaLz​^​=iℏ​∂ϕ∂​L^=rr^×pp^​=rr×iℏ​∇

Solving the Radial Equation

Now we turn our attention to solving the radial equation. The first step is to substitute the form of the Coulomb potential for the proton-electron interaction into the radial equation we obtained earlier. At the same time, we make the substitution u(r)=rR(r)u_{(r)} = rR_{(r)}u(r)​=rR(r)​ to simplify. We have:

−ℏ22μ∂2u∂r2+ℏ22μl(l+1)r2u−e2ru=Elu-\frac {\hbar^2}{2\mu} \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial r^2} +\frac {\hbar^2}{2\mu} \frac{l(l+1)}{r^2}u -\frac{e^2}{r}u = E_lu−2μℏ2​∂r2∂2u​+2μℏ2​r2l(l+1)​u−re2​u=El​u

where e is the charge of an electron.

The part

ℏ22μl(l+1)r2u−e2ru\frac {\hbar^2}{2\mu} \frac{l(l+1)}{r^2}u -\frac{e^2}{r}u2μℏ2​r2l(l+1)​u−re2​u

is known as the effective potential.

First, let’s try to solve this differential equation when l=0l=0l=0. We know from solving the angular equation that l is a quantum number that “labels” wave functions at different energy levels, so finding the solution when l=0l=0l=0 should give us information about the ground state wave function. This will help us understand the most general solutions that we will get later.

Subbing l=0l=0l=0 into the Schrodinger equation and using RRR instead of uuu, we get:

−ℏ22μ[∂2∂r2]R−e2rR=E0R-\frac{\hbar^2}{2\mu} [\frac{\partial^2}{\partial r^2}]R - \frac{e^2}{r}R=E_0R−2μℏ2​[∂r2∂2​]R−re2​R=E0​R

Even without looking at this equation, we know that R has to approach 0 when r approaches infinity, otherwise the wave function cannot be properly normalized. We also know that R needs to be well-behaved at the origin. Keeping these two criteria in mind, it’s sensible to try:

R∝e−κrR \propto e^{-\kappa r}R∝e−κr

we get:

−ℏ22μ[κ2−2κr]e−κr−e2re−κr=E0e−κr-\frac{\hbar^2}{2\mu} [\kappa^2 -\frac{2\kappa}{r}]e^{-\kappa r} - \frac{e^2}{r} e^{-\kappa r} = E_0 e^{-\kappa r}−2μℏ2​[κ2−r2κ​]e−κr−re2​e−κr=E0​e−κr

This equation is true at all rrr, so we need to set the two rrr dependent terms to cancel out each other, which means:

ℏ2κrμ−e2r=0\frac{\hbar^2 \kappa}{r\mu} - \frac{e^2}{r} = 0rμℏ2κ​−re2​=0

and

−ℏ2κ22μ=E0-\frac{\hbar^2 \kappa^2} {2\mu} = E_0−2μℏ2κ2​=E0​

Solving the first equation, we get:

κ=μe2ℏ2\kappa = \frac{\mu e^2}{\hbar^2}κ=ℏ2μe2​

Note that the unit of κ\kappaκ is 1[distance]\frac{1}{[distance]}[distance]1​. We define a0a_0a0​ to be:

a0=1κ=ℏ2μe2a_0 = \frac{1}{\kappa} = \frac{\hbar^2}{\mu e^2}a0​=κ1​=μe2ℏ2​

and consequently:

E0=−e22a0E_0 = -\frac{e^2}{2a_0}E0​=−2a0​e2​

a0a_0a0​ is called the Bohr’s radius. It describes the size of a ground state hydrogen atom. In fact, Bohr’s radius is the average (expectation value of) distance between the proton and the electron at the ground state. The electron exist as a probability cloud, so it only makes sense to talks about the average distance.

Using values obtained from delicate experiments, we now know that:

E0=13.6eVE_0 = 13.6eVE0​=13.6eV

This energy is called the Rydberg constant, it is the energy of a ground state hydrogen atom. This energy is negative because the hydrogen atom is a bound system. The electron needs to absorb at least 1 Rydberg of energy to become unbound.

Now let’s deal with the most general case (l≠0l\ne 0l=0). Before manipulating the radial equation, we need to first determine the form of u(r)u_{(r)}u(r)​ by looking at its asymptotic behaviors.

Remember our radial equation:

−ℏ22μ∂2u∂r2+ℏ22μl(l+1)r2u−e2ru=Elu-\frac {\hbar^2}{2\mu} \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial r^2} +\frac {\hbar^2}{2\mu} \frac{l(l+1)}{r^2}u -\frac{e^2}{r}u = E_lu−2μℏ2​∂r2∂2u​+2μℏ2​r2l(l+1)​u−re2​u=El​u

First consider the case when r→0r\to 0r→0. The 1r2\frac{1}{r^2}r21​ term dominate over the 1r\frac{1}{r}r1​ tern, and we have:

−ℏ22μ∂2u∂r2+ℏ22μl(l+1)r2u=Eu-\frac {\hbar^2}{2\mu} \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial r^2} +\frac {\hbar^2}{2\mu} \frac{l(l+1)}{r^2}u = Eu−2μℏ2​∂r2∂2u​+2μℏ2​r2l(l+1)​u=Eu

Try u=rpu=r^pu=rp as a solution:

−ℏ22μ[p(p−1)−l(l+1)]rp−2=Erp-\frac {\hbar^2}{2\mu} [p(p-1) -l(l+1)]r^{p-2} = Er^p−2μℏ2​[p(p−1)−l(l+1)]rp−2=Erp

The RHS goes to 0 as r→0r\to 0r→0. So we need the expression inside the square bracket equal to 0. Which means:

p(p−1)−l(l+1)=0p(p-1) -l(l+1) = 0p(p−1)−l(l+1)=0 p=l+1,p=−lp=l+1 , p=-lp=l+1,p=−l

We eliminate the p=−lp=-lp=−l solution because it blows up at the origin. So from this r→0r\to 0r→0 case, we know that:

u(r)∝rl+1u_{(r)} \propto r^{l+1}u(r)​∝rl+1

Now let’s consider the case when r→∞r\to \inftyr→∞. We are only left with:

−ℏ22μ∂2u∂r2=Eu-\frac {\hbar^2}{2\mu} \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial r^2} = Eu−2μℏ2​∂r2∂2u​=Eu

We know that E is less than 0 because the hydrogen atom is a bound system. This criterion allows us to quickly solve this differential equation and get:

u(r)∝e±κr2u_{(r)} \propto e^{\pm \frac{\kappa r}{2}}u(r)​∝e±2κr​

Where ℏ2κ22μ=∣E∣\frac{\hbar^2\kappa^2}{2\mu} = |E|2μℏ2κ2​=∣E∣. We can eliminate the +κr2+\frac{\kappa r}{2}+2κr​ solution because it goes to infinity at large rrr.

Now we have two “parts” to the solution of u. In order to make sure that u has the characteristic of both parts, we assume that the “complete” u is a product of the two “parts” and some other arbitrary function that is yet to be determined.

u(r)=rl+1e−κr2F(r)u_{(r)} = r^{l+1}e^{- \frac{\kappa r}{2}} F_{(r)}u(r)​=rl+1e−2κr​F(r)​

To determine the unknown function, we need to return to our radial equation and find its solution. Let’s remind ourselves what it looks like:

−ℏ22μ∂2u∂r2+ℏ22μl(l+1)r2u−e2ru=Elu-\frac {\hbar^2}{2\mu} \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial r^2} +\frac {\hbar^2}{2\mu} \frac{l(l+1)}{r^2}u -\frac{e^2}{r}u = E_lu−2μℏ2​∂r2∂2u​+2μℏ2​r2l(l+1)​u−re2​u=El​u

To simplify things, we make the following definitions:

ϵ=EE0\epsilon = \frac{E}{E_0}ϵ=E0​E​ ρ=4∣ϵ∣ra0\rho = \sqrt{4|\epsilon|} \frac{r}{a_0}ρ=4∣ϵ∣​a0​r​ λ=e2ℏμ2∣E∣\lambda = \frac{e^2}{\hbar} \sqrt{\frac{\mu}{2|E|}}λ=ℏe2​2∣E∣μ​​

Then the differential equation becomes:

∂2u∂ρ2−l(l+1)ρ2u+(λρ−14)u=0\frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial \rho^2} - \frac{l(l+1)}{\rho^2}u + (\frac{\lambda}{\rho} - \frac{1}{4})u = 0∂ρ2∂2u​−ρ2l(l+1)​u+(ρλ​−41​)u=0

Now sub in the form of u(r)u_{(r)}u(r)​ we obtained earlier and solve using a power series expansion on F, the unknown function. After MUCH algebra, we get:

F(ρ)=∑k=0∞ρkk!F_{(\rho)} = \sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac{\rho^{k}}{k!}F(ρ)​=k=0∑∞​k!ρk​

and the power series terminates when

n=λ=kmax+l+1n=\lambda = k_{max} +l+1n=λ=kmax​+l+1

n is called the primary quantum number and is used together with the azimuthal and magnetic quantum number to label a state/wave function. In fact, you can check that the Hamiltonian H^\hat HH^ commutes with L^2\hat{L}^2L^2 and Lz^\hat{L_z}Lz​^​, so that we can label the state of a hydrogen atom by

∣n,l,m⟩|n, l, m\rangle∣n,l,m⟩

For a given nnn, l=0,1,2,⋯ ,n−1l=0,1,2, \cdots, n-1l=0,1,2,⋯,n−1, and for a given lll, m=−l,−l+1,⋯ ,l−1,lm=-l,-l+1, \cdots, l-1,lm=−l,−l+1,⋯,l−1,l, which means for a given nnn, there are n2n^2n2 possible energy states.

Labeling using these three quantum numbers is equivalent to the naming conventions for the orbitals in chemistry. l=0l=0l=0 corresponds to the s-orbital, l=1l=1l=1 corresponds to the p-orbital, and so on. The three dimensional shapes of the orbitals are determined by the wave functions we solves (three parts multiplied together).

Lastly, from the equality between n and λ\lambdaλ, we can get:

n=λ=e2ℏμ2∣E∣n=\lambda = \frac{e^2}{\hbar}\sqrt{\frac{\mu}{2|E|}}n=λ=ℏe2​2∣E∣μ​​ En=−e4μℏ22n2=−e22a01n2E_n = -\frac{e^4\mu}{\hbar^2 2n^2} = -\frac{e^2}{2a_0} \frac{1}{n^2}En​=−ℏ22n2e4μ​=−2a0​e2​n21​

Which means for all energy states, we have:

En=E0n2    ⟨r⟩=a0n2E_n = \frac{E_0}{n^2} \; \; \langle r\rangle = a_0 n^2En​=n2E0​​⟨r⟩=a0​n2

frontmatter.title: Quantum Mechanics 07 - The Hydrogen Atom
frontmatter.description: Starting from this post, we are going to apply the techniques we learned in QM to solve some real-world problems. In this post, we are going to describe the hydrogen atom with Quantum Mechanics!
